newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea drafts laws to set up bad loans fund.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea drafts laws to set up bad loans fund.

text.p: South Korea's Finance and Economy Ministry said on Wednesday it had drafted legislation establishing a fund to address the problem of corporate bankruptcies.
The legislation would designate state-funded Korea Asset Management Corp to run the fund, which would be capitalised at 1.5 trillion won, a ministry statement said.
The ministry will submit the draft to parliament in June for approval.
The Management Corp, whose paid-in capital is 200 billion won, would be expanded and reshaped.
The statement said the fund would be operational for five years and would be financed mainly with contributions from banks, bond issues and borrowings.
The goal of the fund would be to "speed up and rationalise" the handling of bad loans, reduce losses of companies, banks and creditors and minimise disorder in the banking system, it said.
The ministry estimated bad debts held by the nation's commercial banks at about 2.4 trillion won at the end of 1996, the statement said.
It described bad debt as debt on which payment is doubtful.
The organisation would buy mortgaged bad debts from financial institutions, repackage and later sell them.
The finance ministry is negotiating with the Home Affairs Ministry to grant tax benefits for the Management Corp to buy or sell the mortgages.
A ministry official said the government was also considering extending tax benefits to buyers but that nothing had been finalised.
